intro: Chorizanthe xanti subsp. leucotheca, commonly known as the whiteflower desert parsley, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its basal rosette of blue-gray, hairy leaves and its clusters of small, white to pale yellow flowers. The plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in sandy or gravelly soils. It belongs to the Amaranthaceae family and is adapted to withstand drought conditions through its succulent leaves and deep root system. The subspecies is distinguished by its pale flower color, which sets it apart from other members of the Chorizanthe genus.
